fields.Speaker Notes:
Ya‚Äôahowu fefu.

T√∂igu Anugrah No‚Äôin√∂t√∂ G√∂ri, ya‚Äôo moroi ba Dan√∂ Niha, Indonesia.
Sinduhu nia,ambo-amb√∂ ya‚Äôodo ba wohede,in√∂n√∂ fo‚Äôamb√∂tagu ba wo‚Äôoguna‚Äô√∂ li da‚Äôa. Ba hiza‚Äôi, ube‚Äôe-be‚Äôe man√∂ ua. Fefu wehede ni‚Äôoguna‚Äô√∂gu iada‚Äôa wehede nifakegu ba nomo. Andr√∂, l√∂ atul√∂ si‚Äôai dania wehedegu da‚Äôa.

Omasido ua u fatun√∂ kh√∂mi so‚Äôamakhoita ba kh√∂gu sam√∂sa. Ba d√∂igu so t√∂lu faosat√∂. Anugrah, moroi ba Li Indonesia, si g√∂i nifiza moroi ba Li Sans√∂k√∂rta. No‚Äôin√∂t√∂, l√∂ tola l√∂ √∂‚Äôila eluaha nia na √∂‚Äôila fa Li Niha. Na G√∂ri, sambua mado bada‚Äôa. L√∂ ato ndra‚Äôaga mado da‚Äôa w√∂ sa.

Ndr√∂figu fele witu fakhe. Ya‚Äôodo nono numero dua moroi dalima sifatalifus√∂. Fefu ndra‚Äôaga no m√∂i zikola. Ga‚Äôagu ihal√∂ sikola salawa nia, ya‚Äôodo tohude si fele ndrua, ndra akhigu tohude si fulu, walu, ba g√∂i lima.

Awena g√∂i ir√∂i ndra‚Äôaga satuama iramatua ndr√∂fi silal√∂. Hat√∂ ninama sitor√∂i bada'a sobalazoini ndra‚Äôaga. Asese ahakh√∂ d√∂d√∂gu na ufaigi-faigi ba g√∂i na it√∂r√∂ t√∂d√∂gu ia. Hat√∂ fangandr√∂ si tola ube‚Äôe kh√∂ nia ba gin√∂t√∂ andre.

Ba ndr√∂fi f√∂nada g√∂i, awai sikolagu. Ba omasido utohug√∂ ba sikola salawa. Omasido ufomaha ya‚Äôodo so‚Äôamakhoita ba li ma wehede.

Hana wa‚Äôomasi ya‚Äôo da‚Äô√∂? B√∂r√∂ i‚Äôotarai me ide-idedo, asese ya‚Äôodo mombaso. Ba wombasogu mbuku, oya fanofu kh√∂gu. Ya‚Äôia da‚Äô√∂ hadia Li si‚Äôof√∂na la‚Äôoguna‚Äô√∂ ba gulidan√∂, hana wa oya niha so‚Äôoguna‚Äô√∂ Li Ingglisi, ba tan√∂ b√∂‚Äô√∂ nia. Fangandr√∂gu, us√∂ndra dania sin√∂ndra nia ba sikola salawa dania.

Da‚Äôa g√∂i hana wa‚Äôomasido fao ba Wikitongu andre. Omasido ena‚Äô√∂ l√∂ ataya li ma ndra Ono Niha ba gin√∂t√∂ f√∂na.

Uduh√∂ wehedegu, saohag√∂l√∂ no mifondrondongo li gu. Ya falukha ita ba d√∂f... (wrong speech), ya falukha ita ba gin√∂t√∂ f√∂nada.
fields.Video Description: This video was recorded in the province of North Sumatra, Indonesia and features Nias speaker Anugrah No'in√µt√µ G√µri. Nias, also called Li Niha by its native speakers, was spoken by about 770,000 people as of a 2000 census. A language of the Northwest Sumatra-Barrier Islands, Nias belongs to the Malayo-Polynesian branch of the Austronesian language family. It is typically divided into three recognized dialects: Northern, South, and Central. Nias makes use of consonant mutation (the changing word-initial consonants) to mark some cases, as opposed to other methods such as suffixation. An initial 'n' or 'g' before a vowel becomes semantically distinct, such as that between "n√∂ri" ('village federation') and "g√∂ri" ('bracelet'). Nias is similar to languages like Basque, Gorgian, Mayan, and Tibetan in that it follows ergative-absolutive alignment, contrasting with languages like English that take nominative-accusative alignment.
YouTube License Statement: This video is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International license. To download a copy, please contact hello@wikitongues.org.
